channel.title: Articles by Edward Martel on Tech Terminologies
channel.description: Recent content in Articles by Edward Martel on Tech Terminologies

item.title: What is Run-length Encoding?
item.description: Run-length encoding is a simple method of compressing data by identifying and replacing repeated sequences of identical data with a single instance of that data, along with a count of how many times it appears in the original file.

item.title: What is a PIN (Personal Identification Number)?
item.description: A Personal Identification Number, or PIN, is a numerical code used to authenticate a user’s identity and protect against unauthorized access.

item.title: What is APT (Advanced Persistent Threat)?
item.description: An Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) is a type of cyberattack that is typically launched by a nation-state or other highly organized and funded group.

item.title: What is a Standalone App?
item.description: A standalone app is a software application that is designed to be self-contained and runs independently on a device without the need for an internet connection or the support of any other external program.

item.title: What is a Portable App?
item.description: A portable app is a software program that can be run from a removable storage device, such as a USB flash drive, without the need for installation or setup on the host computer.

item.title: What is Ultra DMA (Ultra Direct Memory Access)?
item.description: Ultra DMA (Ultra Direct Memory Access) is a data transfer technology used in computers to improve the speed of data transfer between the computer’s hard disk drive and the system memory.

item.title: What is Torrent?
item.description: Torrent is a file-sharing technology that allows users to download and share large files, for example, movies, music, and software, over the internet.

item.title: What is a Swap File?
item.description: A swap file, also known as a swap space or a paging file, is a space on a hard drive or other storage device that is used to store data temporarily when the system’s main memory (RAM) becomes full.

item.title: What is Metadata?
item.description: The term “metadata” refers to any data that contains information about other types of data.

item.title: What is a CLI (Command-Line Interface)?
item.description: A command-line interface (CLI) is a text-based interface that allows users to interact with a computer by typing commands and receiving output.

item.title: What is GNU (GNU's Not Unix)?
item.description: GNU is a free software operating system that was created in 1983 by Richard Stallman.

item.title: What is a Browser Extension?
item.description: A browser extension is a small software program that adds additional functionality to a web browser.

item.title: What is a Honeypot?
item.description: A honeypot is a security system that is designed to attract and “trap” malicious cyber activity.

item.title: What is a Cybersquatter?
item.description: A cybersquatter is an individual or organization that registers, traffics in, or uses a domain name in bad faith with the intent to benefit from the reputation of another person’s trademark.

item.title: What is the 403 Error (Forbidden)?
item.description: A 403 error is an HTTP status code that indicates that a client is forbidden from accessing a requested resource.

item.title: What is NFC (Near Field Communication)?
item.description: Near Field Communication (NFC) is a short-range wireless technology that allows for the exchange of data or power between devices.

item.title: What is Parity Check?
item.description: “Parity check” is a method of checking the accuracy of data transmission or storage.

item.title: What is Golden Copy?
item.description: A “golden copy,” also known as the “final version” or “release version,” is a term used to describe the last version of a software product that has been thoroughly tested and is ready for distribution or deployment.

item.title: What is Golden Image?
item.description: A “golden image,” also known as a “golden master” or “reference image,” is the final version of a software application that has been thoroughly tested and approved for production use.

item.title: What is Encoding?
item.description: Encoding is the process of converting data from one format into another for the purpose of efficient transmission or storage.

item.title: What is ACL (Access Control List)?
item.description: An access control list (ACL) is a list of permissions that are associated with a particular resource, such as a file, folder, or network device.

item.title: What is Barebones?
item.description: A barebones PC is a computer that comes with only the essential components, such as a motherboard, processor, and power supply.
